aberrant.example: When the financial director started screaming and throwing food at his co-workers, the police had to come in to deal with his aberrant behavior.
aberrant.meaning: markedly different from an accepted norm

aberration.example: Aberrations in climate have become the norm: rarely a week goes by without some meteorological phenomenon making headlines.
aberration.meaning: a deviation from what is normal or expected

abstain.example: Considered a health nut, Jessica abstained from anything containing sugar--even chocolate.
abstain.meaning: choose not to consume or take part in (particularly something enjoyable)

abstruse.example: Physics textbooks can seem so abstruse to the uninitiated that readers feel as though they are looking at hieroglyphics.

accolade.example: Jean Paul-Sartre was not a fan of accolades, and as such, he refused to accept the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1964.
accolade.meaning: an award or praise granted as a special honor

acerbic.example: Most movie critics are acerbic towards summer blockbusters, often referring to them as garbage.

acrimony.example: The acrimonious dispute between the president and vice-president sent a clear signal to voters: the health of the current administration was imperiled.

adamant.example: Civil rights icon Rosa Parks will forever be remembered for adamantly refusing to give up her seat on a public bus--even after the bus driver insisted, she remained rooted in place.

admonish.example: Before the concert began, security personel admonished the crowd not to come up on stage during the performance.
admonish.meaning: to warn strongly, even to the point of reprimanding

admonitory.example: At the assembly, the high school vice-principal gave the students an admonitory speech, warning them of the many risks and dangers of prom night.
admonitory.meaning: serving to warn; expressing reproof or reproach especially as a corrective

aesthete.example: A true aesthete, Marty would spend hours at the Guggenheim Museum, staring at the same Picasso.
aesthete.meaning: one who professes great sensitivity to the beauty of art and nature

aesthetic.example: The director, not known for his aesthetic sensibilities, decided not to use costumes at all, and put on the play in everyday clothing.
aesthetic.meaning: concerned with the appreciation of beauty

aesthetic.example: movement. The artist operated according to a peculiar aesthetic, not considering any photograph to be worth publishing unless it contained a marine mammal.
aesthetic.meaning: a set of principles underlying and guiding the work of a particular artist or artistic

amalgam.example: The band's music was an amalgam of hip-hop, flamenco and jazz, blending the three styles with surprising results.

ambiguous.example: The coach told his team, "Move towards that side of the field"; because he did not point, his directions were ambiguous, and the team had no idea to which side he was referring.
ambiguous.meaning: open to more than one interpretation

ambivalent.example: Sam was ambivalent about studying for the exam because doing so ate up a lot of his time, yet he was able to improve his analytical skills.
ambivalent.meaning: mixed or conflicting emotions about something

ameliorate.example: Three Cups of Tea tells the story of western man who hopes to ameliorate poverty and the lack of education in Afghanistan.

amenable.example: Even though she did not like the outdoors, Shirley was generally amenable and so her brother was able to persuade her to go camping.

amorphous.example: His study plan for the GRE was at best amorphous; he would do questions from random pages in any one of seven test prep books.

anomalous.example: According to those who do not believe in climate change, the extreme weather over the last five years is simply anomalous--average temps should return to average, they believe.

anomaly.example: After finding an anomaly in the data, she knew that she would have to conduct her experiment again.
anomaly.meaning: something that is not normal, standard, or expected

antipathy.example: Maria had an antipathy for tour groups, often bolting to the other side of the museum as soon as she saw a chaperone leading a group of wide-eyed tourists.
antipathy.meaning: an intense feeling of dislike or aversion

antithetical.example: His deep emotional involvement with these ideas is, in fact, antithetical to the disattachment Buddhism preaches.
antithetical.meaning: sharply contrasted in character or purpose

apathetic.example: Mr. Thompson was so talented at teaching math that even normally apathetic students took interest.
apathetic.meaning: marked by a lack of interest

apathy.example: Widespread apathy among voters led to a very small turnout on election day.
apathy.meaning: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm

apocryphal.example: The web is notorious for sandwiching apocryphal stories between actual news.

appease.example: Neville Chamberlain, the British prime minister during WWII, tried to appease Hitler and in doing so sent a clear message: you can walk all over us.
appease.meaning: pacify by acceding to the demands of

arbitrary.example: One of the arbitrary decrees in place during the emperor's rule is that all citizens pay him weekly homage at his palace.
arbitrary.meaning: based on a random, groundless decision
arbitrary.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

arcane.example: Most college fraternities are known for arcane rituals that those hoping to the join the fraterntiy must learn.

arduous.example: In order to deal with the arduous cross-country journey, truck drivers often survive on a string of caffeinated drinks, staying awake for up to 30 hours at a time.
arduous.meaning: demanding considerable mental effort and skill; testing powers of endurance

artful.example: Picasso is generally considered the most artful member of the Cubist movement.
Bernie Madoff's artful Ponzi scheme stole billions of dollars from investors and is considered the largest financial fraud in U.S. history.

ascetic.example: His ascetic life is the main reason he inspired so many followers, especially since he gave up wealth and power to live in poverty.
Historically, ascetics like Ghandi are often considered wise men partially because of their restraint.

askance.example: The old couple looked askance on the teenagers seated next to them, whispering to each other, "They've got rings through their noses and purple hair!"
askance.meaning: with a look of suspicion or disapproval

audacious.example: As all of the other campers cowered in their tents, Bill, armed only with a flashlight, audaciously tracked down the bear that had raided their food.
audacious.meaning: willing to be bold in social situations or to take risks

audacity.example: She surprised her colleagues by having the audacity to publically criticize the findings of an distinguished scientist.

auspicious.example: Despite an auspicious beginning, Mike's road trip became a series of mishaps, and he was soon stranded and penniless, leaning against his wrecked automobile.

austere.example: His lifestyle of revelry and luxurious excess could hardly be called austere.
Late Soviet architecture, although remaining largely austere, moved into experimental territory that employed previously unused shapes and structures.
The principal of my elementary school was a cold, austere woman; I could never understand why she chose to work with children.

avaricious.example: Since avaricious desire is similar to gluttony or lust--sins of excess--it was listed as one of the seven deadly sins by the Catholic church.

banal.example: The professor used such banal expression that many students in the class either fell asleep from bordeom or stayed awake to complete his sentences and humor friends.
banal.meaning: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse

banality.example: Herbert regarded the minister's remark as a mere banality until Sharon pointed out profound implications to the seemingly obvious words.

belie.example: The smile on her face belies the pain she must feel after the death of her husband.
belie.meaning: to give a false representation to; misrepresent

belligerent.example: Tom said that he was arguing the matter purely for philosophical reasons, but his belligerent tone indicated an underlying anger about the issue.
belligerent.meaning: characteristic of one eager to fight

betray.example: With the gold medal at stake, the gymnast awaited his turn, his quivering lip betraying his intense emotions.
betray.meaning: to reveal or make known something, usually unintentionally

blatant.example: Allen was often punished in school for blatantly disrespecting teachers.
blatant.meaning: without any attempt at concealment; completely obvious

bolster.example: The case for the suspect's innocence was bolstered considerably by the fact that neither fingerprints nor DNA were found at the scene.
bolster.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

brazen.example: Their large "donations" to the local police department gave the drug cartel the brazen confidence to do their business out in the open.

bucolic.example: The noble families of England once owned vast expanses of beautiful, bucolic land.
bucolic.meaning: relating to the pleasant aspects of the country

bumbling.example: Within a week of starting, the bumbling new waiter was unceremoniously fired.
bumbling.meaning: lacking physical movement skills, especially with the hands

burgeon.example: China's housing market is burgeoning, but some predict that the growth is merely a bubble and will burst much like the U.S. real estate bubble of 2008.

calumny.example: With the presidential primaries well under way, the air is thick with calumny, and the mud already waisthigh.
calumny.meaning: making of a false statement meant to injure a person"s reputation

capricious.example: Nearly every month our capricious CEO had a new plan to turn the company around, and none of them worked because we never gave them the time they needed to succeed.
capricious.meaning: determined by chance or impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason

castigate.example: Drill sergeants are known to castigate new recruits so mercilessly that the latter often break down during their first week in training.

censure.example: After being caught in bed with a mistress, the mayor was quickly censured by the city council.

chastise.example: Though chastised for his wanton abuse of the pantry, Lawrence shrugged off his mother's harsh words, and continued to plow through jars of cookies and boxes of donuts.

chortle.example: Walking past the bar, I could hear happy, chortling people and the blast of horns from a jazz band.

circumscribe.example: Their tour of South America was circumscribed so that they saw only popular destinations and avoided the dangerous parts of cities.
circumscribe.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

circumvent.example: One way of circumventing the GRE is to apply to a grad school that does not require GRE scores.
circumvent.meaning: cleverly find a way out of one's duties or obligations

commensurate.example: The convicted felon's life sentence was commensurate to the heinousness of his crime.
commensurate.meaning: to be in proportion or corresponding in degree or amount

concede.example: After a long, stern lecture from her father, Olivia conceded to having broken the window.
The Spanish were forced to concede much of the territory they had previously conquered.
concede.meaning: give over; surrender or relinquish to the physical control of another

confound.example: Though Harry loved numbers, he found calculus confounding.
Americans often confound sweet potatoes with yams, and refer to both vegetables by the same name.

conspicuous.example: American basketball players are always conspicuous when they go abroad--not only are they American, but some are over seven feet tall.
conspicuous.meaning: without any attempt at concealment; completely obvious

constituent.example: The mayor's constituents are no longer happy with her performance and plan to vote for another candidate in the upcoming election.
constituent.meaning: a citizen who is represented in a government by officials for whom he or she votes

constituent.example: The constituents of the metal alloy are nickle, copper, and tin.

construe.example: The author's inability to take a side on the issue was construed by both his opponents and supporters as a sign of weakness.

contingent.example: A small contingent of those loyal to the king have gathered around the castle to defend it.
contingent.meaning: a gathering of persons representative of some larger group

contingent.example: Whether the former world champions can win again this year is contingent upon none of its star players getting injured.
contingent.meaning: possible but not certain to occur

contrition.example: Those who show contrition during their prison terms--especially when under review by a parole board-often get shortened sentences.
contrition.meaning: the feeling of remorse or guilt that comes from doing something bad

contrive.example: Despite a low GPA, he contrived to get into college, going so far as to write his own glowing letters of recommendation.
contrive.meaning: to pull off a plan or scheme, usually through skill or trickery
contrive.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

copious.example: In midsummer, there are copious popiscle stands at the beach; in the winter, there are none.

craven.example: Though the man could have at least alerted the police, he crouched cravenly in the corner as the old woman was mugged.

cryptic.example: Since Sarah did not want her husband to guess the Christmas present she had bought him, she only answered cryptically when he would ask her questions about it.

culminate.example: Beethoven's musical genius culminated in the 9th Symphony, which many consider his greatest work.
culminate.meaning: reach the highest or most decisive point

culpability.example: Since John had left his banana peel at the top of the stairwell, he accepted culpability for Martha's broken leg.

decorous.example: Sally's parties are decorous affairs, and instead of the usual beer and music, there is tea and intellectual conversation.
decorous.meaning: characterized by good taste in manners and conduct

decorum.example: You will obey the rules of decorum for this courtroom or spend the night in a jail cell, said the judge to the prosecutor.

deferential.example: If you ever have the chance to meet the president, stand up straight and be deferential.

deleterious.example: The BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was deleterious to the fishing industry in the southern states.

delineate.example: After a brief summary of proper swimming technique, the coach delineated the specifics of each stroke, spending 30 minutes alone on the backstroke.

demur.example: Wallace disliked the cold, so he demurred when his friends suggested they going skiing in the Alps.

denigrate.example: someone Count Rumford denigrated the new theory of heat, demonstrating that it was wholly inadequate to explain the observations.
denigrate.meaning: charge falsely or with malicious intent; attack the good name and reputation of

denote.example: Even if the text is not visible, the red octagon denotes "stop" to all motorists in America.
denote.meaning: be a sign or indication of; have as a meaning

derivative.example: work of another person Because the movies were utterly derivative of other popular movies, they did well at the box office.
derivative.meaning: (or a creative product, e.g. music, writing, etc.) not original but drawing on the
derivative.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

derive.example: Many words in the English language are derived from Latin, including the word "derive."
derive.meaning: come from; be connected by a relationship of blood, for example

derive.example: From the multiple set of footprints in the living room, the investigator derived an important clue: Sheila was not alone in the room at the time of the murder.
derive.meaning: reason by deduction; establish by deduction

dictatorial.example: The coach was dictatorial in his approach: no players could ever argue or question his approach.
dictatorial.meaning: expecting unquestioning obedience; characteristic of an absolute ruler

didactic.example: Tolstoy's The Death of Ivan Illyich is a didactic novel, instructing the reader on how to live a good life.

diffident.example: As a young girl she was diffident and reserved, but now as an adult, she is confident and assertive.

dilatory.example: Lawyers use dilatory tactics so that it takes years before the case is actually decided.

dilettante.example: to have knowledge Fred has no formal medical training; while he likes to claim authority on medical issues, he is little more than a dilettante
dilettante.meaning: an amateur who engages in an activity without serious intentions and who pretends

disaffected.example: After watching his superior take rations from the soliders, he quickly became disaffected and rebeled.

discrete.example: What was once known as Czechoslovakia has since split into two discrete, independent nations.
discrete.meaning: constituting a separate entity or part

disinterested.example: The potential juror knew the defendant, and therefore could not serve on the jury, which must consist only of disinterested members.

dispassionate.example: A good scientist should be dispassionate, focusing purely on what the evidence says, without personal attachment.
dispassionate.meaning: unaffected by strong emotion or prejudice

disseminate.example: Before the effects of anaethesia were disseminated, patients had to experience the full pain of a surgery.

dogmatic.example: Bryan is dogmatic in his belief that the earth is flat, claiming that all pictures of a spherical earth are computer generated.
dogmatic.meaning: highly opinionated, not accepting that your belief may not be correct

duress.example: The witness said he signed the contract under duress and argued that the court should cancel the agreement.

eclectic.example: Joey was known for his eclectic tastes in music, one moment dancing to disco the next "air conducting" along to Beethoven's 9th symphony.
eclectic.meaning: comprised of a variety of styles

economical.example: Journalists favor an economical style of writing, in which no unnecessary words are used and every sentence is as short as possible.

edifying.example: I recently read an article in the Times about whether good literature is edifying or not; specifically, does reading more make a person more moral.
edifying.meaning: enlightening or uplifting so as to encourage intellectual or moral improvement

efficacious.example: Since Maggie's cough syrup, which had expired five years back, was no longer efficacious, she coughed through the night.

egregious.example: The dictator's abuse of human rights was so egregious that many world leaders asked that he be tried in an international court for genocide.
egregious.meaning: standing out in negative way; shockingly bad

elicit.example: Just smiling--even if you are depressed--can elicit feelings of pleasure and happiness.

elucidate.example: Youtube is great place to learn just about anything--an expert elucidates finer points so that even a complete novice can learn.
elucidate.meaning: make clearer and easier to understand

eminent.example: Shakespeare is an eminent author in the English language, but I find his writing uninteresting and melodramatic.
eminent.meaning: standing above others in quality or position

enervate.example: John preferred to avoid equatorial countries; the intense sun would always leave him enervated after he'd spent the day sightseeing.

engender.example: The restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles were so severe that they engendered deep hatred and resentment in the German people.

entrenched.example: By the time we reach 60-years old, most of our habits are so entrenched that it is difficult for us to change.

ephemeral.example: The lifespan of a mayfly is ephemeral, lasting from a few hours to a couple of days.

equivocal.example: The findings of the study were equivocal--the two researchers had different opinions on what the results signified.

eradicate.example: I tried eradicating the mosquitos in my apartment with a rolled up newspaper, but there were too many of them.

erudite.example: Before the Internet, the library was typically were you would find erudite readers.

eschew.example: Politicians are the masters of eschewing morals; academics are the masters of eschewing clarity.
eschew.meaning: avoid and stay away from deliberately; stay clear of

esoteric.example: Map collecting is an esoteric hobby to most, but to geography geeks it is a highly enjoyable pasttime.
esoteric.meaning: confined to and understandable by only an enlightened inner circle

espouse.example: As a college student, Charlie espoused Marxism, growing his beard out and railing against the evils of the free-market.
espouse.meaning: to adopt or support an idea or cause

exacerbate.example: Her sleeplessness exacerbated her cold--when she woke up the next day, her sinuses were completely blocked.

exacting.example: Though his childhood piano teacher was so exacting, Max is thankful now, as a professional pianist.

exalt.example: The teenagers exalted the rock star, covering their bedrooms with posters of him.

exonerate.example: The document clearly indicated that Nick was out of the state at the time of the crime, and so served to exonerate him of any charges.
exonerate.meaning: pronounce not guilty of criminal charges

expound.example: The CEO refused to expound on the decision to merge our department with another one, and so I quit.
expound.meaning: add details or explanation; clarify the meaning; state in depth

extant.example: Despite many bookstores closing, experts predict that some form of book dealing will still be extant generations from now.

fallacious.example: The widespread belief that Eskimos have forty different words for snow is fallacious, based on one false report.
fallacious.meaning: of a belief that is based on faulty reasoning

fastidious.example: Whitney is fastidious about her shoes, arranging them on a shelf in a specific order, each pair evenly spaced.

flux.example: Ever since Elvira resigned as the head of marketing, everything about our sales strategy has been in a state of flux.
flux.meaning: a state of uncertainty about what should be done (usually following some important event)

foment.example: After having his pay cut, Phil spread vicious rumors about his boss, hoping to foment a general feeling of discontent.
foment.meaning: try to stir up public opinion

forlorn.example: After her third pet dog died, Marcia was simply forlorn: this time even the possibility of buying a new dog no longer held any joy.

forthcoming.example: The President announced that the senators were about to reach a compromise, and that he was eager to read the forthcoming details of the bill.
forthcoming.meaning: available when required or as promised

forthcoming.example: As a husband, Larry was not forthcoming: if Jill didn't demand to know details, Larry would never share them with her.
forthcoming.meaning: at ease in talking to others

fortuitous.example: While the real objects are vastly different sizes in space, the sun and the moon seem to have the same fortuitous size in the sky.
fortuitous.meaning: occurring by happy chance; having no cause or apparent cause

frivolous.example: Compared to Juliet's passionate concern for human rights, Jake's non-stop concern about football seems somewhat frivolous.
frivolous.meaning: not serious in content or attitude or behavior

frugal.example: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.
frugal.meaning: not spending much money (but spending wisely)

frustrate.example: I thought I would finish writing the paper by lunchtime, but a number of urgent interruptions served to frustrate my plan.
frustrate.meaning: hinder or prevent (the efforts, plans, or desires) of
frustrate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

furtive.example: While at work, George and his boss Regina felt the need to be as furtive as possible about their romantic relationship.
furtive.meaning: marked by quiet and caution and secrecy; taking pains to avoid being observed

gainsay.example: I can't gainsay a single piece of evidence James has presented, but I still don't trust his conclusion.
gainsay.meaning: deny or contradict; speak against or oppose

gall.example: Even though Carly was only recently hired, she had the gall to question her boss's judgment in front of the office.
gall.meaning: the trait of being rude and impertinent

gall.example: In an act of gall, Leah sent compromising photos of her ex-boyfriend to all his co-workers and professional contacts.
gall.meaning: feeling of deep and bitter anger and ill-will

galvanize.example: At mile 23 of his first marathon, Kyle had all but given up, until he noticed his friends and family holding a banner that read, "Go Kyle"; galvanized, he broke into a gallop, finishing the last three miles in less than 20 minutes.
galvanize.meaning: to excite or inspire (someone) to action

garrulous.example: Lynne was garrulous: once, she had a fifteen minute conversation with a stranger before she realized the woman didn't speak English.

gauche.example: Sylvester says the most gauche things, such as telling a girl he liked that she was much prettier when she wore makeup.

germane.example: The professor wanted to tell the jury in detail about his new book, but the lawyer said it wasn't germane to the charges in the cases.

glut.example: The Internet offers such a glut of news related stories that many find it difficult to know which story to read first.
In the middle of economic crises, hiring managers find their inboxes glutted with resumes.

gossamer.example: The gossamer wings of a butterfly, which allow it to fly, are also a curse, so delicate that they are often damaged.
gossamer.meaning: characterized by unusual lightness and delicacy

gregarious.example: Often we think that great leaders are those who are gregarious, always in the middle of a large group of people; yet, as Mahatma Gandhi and many others have shown us, leaders can also be introverted.
gregarious.meaning: to be likely to socialize with others

guileless.example: At first I thought my niece was guileless, but I then found myself buying her ice cream every time we passed a shop.

hackneyed.example: Cheryl rolled her eyes when she heard the lecturer's hackneyed advice to "be true to yourself."
hackneyed.meaning: lacking significance through having been overused

haphazard.example: Many golf courses are designed with great care, but the greens on the county golf course seem entirely haphazard.
haphazard.meaning: marked by great carelessness; dependent upon or characterized by chance

harangue.example: Dinner at Billy's was more a punishment than a reward, since anyone who sat at the dinner table would have to listen to Billy's father's interminable harangues against the government.
harangue.meaning: a long pompous speech; a tirade

harangue.example: Tired of his parents haranguing him about his laziness and lack of initiative, Tyler finally moved out of home at the age of thirty-five.
harangue.meaning: to deliver a long pompous speech or tirade

harried.example: With a team of new hires to train, Martha was constantly harried with little questions and could not focus on her projects.
harried.meaning: troubled persistently especially with petty annoyances

haughty.example: unworthy The haughty manager didn't believe that any of his subordinates could ever have an insight as brilliant his own.
haughty.meaning: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as

hegemony.example: Until the Spanish Armada was defeated in 1587, Spain had hegemony over the seas, controlling waters stretching as far as the Americas.

heretic.example: Though everybody at the gym told Mikey to do cardio before weights, Mikey was a heretic and always did the reverse.
heretic.meaning: a person who holds unorthodox opinions in any field (not merely religion)

iconoclast.example: Lady Gaga, in challenging what it means to be clothed, is an iconoclast for wearing a "meat dress" to a prominent awards show.
iconoclast.meaning: somebody who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions

iconoclastic.example: Jackson Pollack was an iconoclastic artist, totally breaking with tradition by splashing paint on a blank canvas.

idiosyncrasy.example: Peggy's numerous idiosyncrasies include wearing mismatched shoes, laughing loudly to herself, and owning a pet aardvark.
idiosyncrasy.meaning: a behavioral attribute that is distinctive and peculiar to an individual

ignoble.example: In the 1920s, the World Series was rigged--an ignoble act which baseball took decades to recover from.

ignominious.example: Since the politician preached ethics and morality, his texting of revealing photographs was ignominious, bringing shame on both himself and his party.
ignominious.meaning: (used of conduct or character) deserving or bringing disgrace or shame

immutable.example: Taxes are one of the immutable laws of the land, so there is no use arguing about paying them.

impartial.example: The judge was not impartial since he had been bribed by the witness's family.
impartial.meaning: free from undue bias or preconceived opinions

impertinent.example: Dexter, distraught over losing his pet dachshund, Madeline, found the police officer's questions impertinent--after all, he thought, did she have to pry into such details as to what Madeline's favorite snack was?
impertinent.meaning: being disrespectful; improperly forward or bold

implacable.example: Win or lose, the coach was always implacable, never giving the athletes an easy practice or a break.
implacable.meaning: incapable of making less angry or hostile

implausible.example: The teacher found it implausible that the student was late to school because he had been kidnapped by outlaws on horseback.
implausible.meaning: describing a statement that is not believable

imprudent.example: Hitler, like Napoleon, made the imprudent move of invading Russia in winter, suffering even more casualties than Napoleon had.

impudent.example: In an impudent move, the defendant spoke out of order to say terribly insulting things to the judge.

incisive.example: The lawyer had an incisive mind, able in a flash to dissect a hopelessly tangled issue and isolate the essential laws at play.
incisive.meaning: having or demonstrating ability to recognize or draw fine distinctions

incongruous.example: The vast economic inequality of modern society is incongruous with America's ideals.
incongruous.meaning: lacking in harmony or compatibility or appropriateness

incorrigible.example: Tom Sawyer seems like an incorrigible youth until Huck Finn enters the novel; even Sawyer can't match his fierce individual spirit.

indecorous.example: society Eating with elbows on the table is considered indecorous in refined circles.
indecorous.meaning: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is right or proper in polite

indifference.example: In an effort to fight indifference, the president of the college introduced a new, stricter grading system.
indifference.meaning: the trait of seeming not to care

inexorable.example: The rise of the computer was an inexorable shift in technology and culture.

ingenuous.example: Two-years in Manhattan had changed Jenna from an ingenuous girl from the suburbs to a jaded urbanite, unlikely to fall for any ruse, regardless of how elaborate.

ingratiate.example: Even though Tom didn't like his new boss, he decided to ingratiate himself to her in order to advance his career.
ingratiate.meaning: gain favor with somebody by deliberate efforts

inimical.example: Venus, with a surface temperature that would turn rubber to liquid, is inimical to any form of life.

innocuous.example: Everyone found Nancy's banter innocuous--except for Mike, who felt like she was intentionally picking on him.
innocuous.meaning: harmless and doesn"t produce any ill effects

inscrutable.example: His speech was so dense and confusing that many in the audience found it inscrutable.

insidious.example: Plaque is insidious: we cannot see it, but each day it eats away at our enamel, causing cavities and other dental problems.
insidious.meaning: working in a subtle but destructive way

insolent.example: Lilian could not help herself from being insolent, commenting that the Queen's shoes were showing too much toe.

intimate.example: At first Manfred's teachers intimated to his parents that he was not suited to skip a grade; when his parents protested, teachers explicitly told them that, notwithstanding the boy's precocity, he was simply too immature to jump to the 6th grade.
intimate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

intransigent.example: Despite many calls for mercy, the judge remained intransigent, citing strict legal precedence.
intransigent.meaning: unwilling to change one's beliefs or course of action

intrepid.example: Captain Ahab was an intrepid captain whose reckless and fearless style ultimate leads to his downfall.

inveterate.example: He is an inveterate smoker and has told his family and friends that there is no way he will ever quit.

involved.example: The physics lecture became so involved that the undergraduate's eyes glazed over.

irrevocable.example: Once you enter your plea to the court, it is irrevocable so think carefully about what you will say.
irrevocable.meaning: incapable of being retracted or revoked

itinerant.example: Doctors used to be itinerant, traveling between patients' homes.
itinerant.meaning: traveling from place to place to work

jingoism.example: North Korea maintains intense control over its population through a combination of jingoism and cult of personality.

jovial.example: The political candidate and his supporters were jovial once it was clear that she had won.
jovial.meaning: full of or showing high-spirited merriment

jubilant.example: My hardwork paid off, and I was jubilant to receive a perfect score on the GRE.
jubilant.meaning: full of high-spirited delight because of triumph or success

juxtapose.example: The meaning of her paintings comes from a classical style which juxtaposes modern themes.

laconic.example: While Martha always swooned over the hunky, laconic types in romantic comedies, her boyfriends inevitably were very talkative--and not very hunky.
laconic.meaning: one who says very few words

lambast.example: Showing no patience, the manager utterly lambasted the sales team that lost the big account.

languid.example: As the sun beat down and the temperature climbed higher, we spent a languid week lying around the house.
languid.meaning: not inclined towards physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed

largess.example: Uncle Frank was known for his largess, so his nephew was sad when he did not receive a present for his birthday.

laudable.example: To say that Gandhi's actions were laudable is the greatest understatement; he overthrew an empire without violence.

lionize.example: Students in the U.S. learn to lionize Jefferson, Franklin, and Washington because they are the founding fathers of the nation.

magnanimous.example: powerful He was a great sportsman: in defeat he was complementary and in victory he was magnanimous.
magnanimous.meaning: noble and generous in spirit, especially towards a rival or someone less

maintain.example: The scientist maintained that the extinction of dinosaurs was most likely brought about by a drastic change in climate.

maladroit.example: As a child she was quite maladroit, but as an adult, she has become an adept dancer.
maladroit.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

maverick.example: Officer Kelly was a maverick, rarely following police protocols or adopting the conventions for speech common among his fellow officers.
maverick.meaning: someone who exhibits great independence in thought and action

mawkish.example: The film was incredibly mawkish, introducing highly likeable characters only to have them succumb to a devastating illnesses by the end of the movie.
mawkish.meaning: overly sentimental to the point that it is disgusting

mendacity.example: I can forgive her for her mendacity but only because she is a child and is seeing what she can get away with.

mercurial.example: The fact that Ella's moods were as mercurial as the weather was problematic for her relationships--it didn't help that she lived in Chicago.
mercurial.meaning: (of a person) prone to unexpected and unpredictable changes in mood

meticulous.example: The Japanese noodle maker was meticulous in making his noodles and would never let another person take over the task.
meticulous.meaning: marked by extreme care in treatment of details

misconstrue.example: The politician never trusted journalists because he though that they misconstrue his words and misrepresent his positions.

mitigate.example: I can only spend so much time mitigating your disagreements with your wife, and at certain point, you need to do it on your own.
If it weren't for the mitigating circumstances, he would have certainly lost his job.
mitigate.meaning: lessen the severity of an offense

mollify.example: In the morning, Harriat was unable to mollify Harry, if he happened to become angry, unless he had his cup of coffee.
mollify.meaning: to make someone angry less angry; placate

mundane.example: Nancy found doing dishes a thorougly mundane task, although Peter found a kind of Zen pleasure in the chore.
Though we think of the pope as someone always dealing in holy matters, he is also concerned with mundane events, such as deciding when to set his alarm each morning.

munificent.example: Uncle Charley was known for his munificence, giving all seven of his nephews lavish Christmas presents each year.

myopic.example: The company ultimately went out of business because the myopic managers couldn't predict the changes in their industry.
myopic.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

myriad.example: There are a myriad of internet sites hawking pills that claim to boost energy for hours on end.

negligible.example: The GRE tests cumulative knowledge, so if you cram the night before it is, at best, likely to only have a negligible impact on your score.
negligible.meaning: so small as to be meaningless; insignificant

nonplussed.example: Shirley was totally nonplussed when the angry motorist cut her off and then stuck his finger out the window.
nonplussed.meaning: unsure how to act or respond

nuance.example: Because of the nuances involved in this case, I hired an outside consultant to advice us and help.
nuance.meaning: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude

obscure.example: On the Smith's drive through the Grand Canyon, Mr. Smith's big head obscured much of Mrs. Robinson's view, so that she only saw momentary patches of red rock.
obscure.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

obscure.example: Many of the biggest movie stars were once obscure actors who got only bit roles in long forgotten films.
obscure.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

obsequious.example: influential people by flattery The obsequious waiter did not give the couple a moment's peace all through the meal, constantly returning to their table to refill their water glasses and to tell them what a handsome pair they made.
obsequious.meaning: attentive in an ingratiating or servile manner; attempting to win favor from

opaque.example: The meaning of the professor's new research was opaque to most people, so no one asked any questions.
opaque.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

opulence.example: Russian oligarchs are famous for their opulence, living in fancy homes and dining on expensive cavier.
opulence.meaning: wealth as evidenced by sumptuous living

ostentatious.example: Matt wanted to buy stone lions for front of the house, but Cynthia convinced him that such a display would be too ostentatious for a modest house in an unassuming neighborhood.
ostentatious.meaning: intended to attract notice and impress others; tawdry or vulgar

ostracize.example: Later in his life, Leo Tolstoy was ostracized from the Russian Orthodox Church for his writings that contradicted church doctrine.
ostracize.meaning: exclude from a community or group

panache.example: Jim, with his typical panache, came to the wedding reception with a top hat, a cane, and a long cape covered in sequins.

parochial.example: Jasmine was sad to admit it, but her fledgling relationship with Jacob did not work out because his culinary tastes were simply too parochial; "After all," she quipped on her blog, "he considered Chef Boyardee ethnic food."
parochial.meaning: narrowly restricted in scope or outlook

parsimonious.example: Katie is so parsimonious that she only buys a pair of socks if all of her other socks have holes in them.

pedantic.example: Professor Thompson was regarded as an expert in his field, but his lectures were utterly pedantic, focused on rigorous details of the most trivial conventions in the field.
pedantic.meaning: marked by a narrow focus on or display of learning especially its trivial aspects

pedestrian.example: While Nan was always engaged in philosophical speculation, her brother was occupied with far more pedestrian concerns: how to earn a salary and run a household.
pedestrian.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

pejorative.example: Most psychologists object to the pejorative term "shrink", believing that they expand the human mind, not limit it.
pejorative.meaning: expressing disapproval (usu. refers to a term)
pejorative.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

perfidy.example: The lowest circles in Dante's Inferno were for those who had practiced perfidy, and among these, the very lowest was for those, such as Judas, who had been treacherous to one of their benefactors.
perfidy.meaning: an act of deliberate betrayal; a breach of a trust

pernicious.example: The most successful viruses are pernicious: an infected person may feel perfectly healthy for several months while incubating and spreading the virus.
pernicious.meaning: exceedingly harmful; working or spreading in a hidden and injurious way

petulant.example: When Ed first met Ruth, he didn't realize she was so petulant, but now that they are three months into their relationship, Ed feels a day doesn't go by in which she isn't whining about some minor issue.

placate.example: I was able to placate the angry mob of students by promising to bring cookies on Monday.
placate.meaning: cause to be more favorably inclined; gain the good will of

platitude.example: The professor argued that many statements regarded as wise in previous times, such as the Golden Rule, are now regarded as mere platitudes.

poignant.example: After the Montagues and Capulets discover the dead bodies of Romeo and Juliet, in the play's most poignant moment, the two griefstricken familes agree to end their feud once and for all.
poignant.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

polemic.example: The professor launched into a polemic, claiming that Freudian theory was a pack of lies that absolutely destroyed European literary theory.
polemic.meaning: a strong verbal or written attack on someone or something.
polemic.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

posit.example: Initially, Einstein posited a repulsive force to balance Gravity, but then rejected that idea as a blunder.

pragmatic.example: Rather than make a philosophical appeal to the Congressmen, the Speaker decided to take a far more pragmatic approach, making small side-deals that would add votes to his bill.
pragmatic.meaning: guided by practical experience and observation rather than theory

precipitous.example: He was expecting a precipitous rise in the value of a "hot" tech stock, so he was disappointed when it only inched up a dollar or two each day.
precipitous.meaning: done with very great haste and without due deliberation

preclude.example: The manager specified that all other gates be locked, to preclude the possibility of persons without tickets entering the arena undetected.
preclude.meaning: keep from happening or arising; make impossible

precocious.example: (especially in mental aptitude) Though only seven years old, she was a precocious chess prodigy, able to beat players twice her age.
precocious.meaning: characterized by or characteristic of exceptionally early development or maturity

predilection.example: Monte had a predilection for the fine things in life: Cuban cigars, 200 dollar bottles of wine, and trips to the French Riviera.

prescience.example: Baxter's warnings about investing in technology stocks seemed like an act of prescience after the whole market declined significantly.
prescience.meaning: the power to foresee the future

prevaricate.example: The cynic quipped, "There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to prevaricate".
prevaricate.meaning: to speak in an evasive way

prodigal.example: Successful professional athletes who do not fall prey to prodigality seem to be the exception--most live decadent lives.

prodigious.example: After the relatively small homerun totals in the "dead ball" era, Babe Ruth's homerun totals were truly prodigious: every year, he set a new all-time record.
prodigious.meaning: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe

profligate.example: Most lottery winners go from being conservative, frugal types to outright profligates who blow millions on fast cars, lavish homes, and giant yachts.
profligate.meaning: someone who spends money recklessly or wastefully

prolific.example: Schubert was the most prolific composer, producing hundreds of hours of music before he died at the age of 31.

propitious.example: The child's heartbeat is still weak, but I am seeing many propitious signs and I think that she may be healing.
propitious.meaning: presenting favorable circumstances; likely to result in or show signs of success

provincial.example: Maggie's enthusiasm about her high school teams seemed provincial to her college classmates, all of whom were following a nationally ranked college team.
provincial.meaning: characteristic of the a limited perspective; not fashionable or sophisticated

pundit.example: Steven Pinker's credentials are unquestioned as a pundit; he has taught at MIT and Stanford, teaches at Harvard, and has published a number of influential books on cognition, language, and psychology.
pundit.meaning: someone who has been admitted to membership in a scholarly field

qualify.example: If James had made more than $50,000 last year, then he wouldn't have qualified for the low-income scholarship.
qualify.meaning: to be legally competent or capable

qualify.example: Chris qualified his love for San Francisco, adding that he didn't like the weather as much as the weather in Los Angeles.
qualify.meaning: to make less severe; to limit (a statement)

querulous.example: The querulous old woman was begining to wear down even the happier members of the staff with her ceaseless complaining.

quotidian.example: Phil gets so involved thinking about Aristotle's arguments that he totally forgets quotidian concerns, such as exercising and eating regularly.
quotidian.meaning: found in the ordinary course of events

ravenous.example: John didn't each much at all during the week he had the flu, so now that he is regaining his health, it's not surpring that he has a ravenous appetite.
ravenous.meaning: extremely hungry; devouring or craving food in great quantities

rebuke.example: The police chief rebuked the two officers whose irresponsible decisions almost led to the deaths of seven innocent by-standers.

reconcile.example: Peggy was unable to reconcile her kind friend Jane with the cruel and merciless character Jane played on television.

recondite.example: knowledge I found Ulysses recondite and never finished the book, waiting instead to read it with someone else so we could penetrate its meaning together.
recondite.meaning: difficult to penetrate; incomprehensible to one of ordinary understanding or

refractory.example: Used to studious high school students, Martha was unprepared for the refractory Kindgergarteners who neither sat still nor listened to a single word she said.
refractory.meaning: stubbornly resistant to authority or control
refractory.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

refute.example: No one could refute his theories or propositions, and that is why he was esteemed by all his colleagues in the philosophy department.
refute.meaning: prove to be false or incorrect

reproach.example: At first, Sarah was going to yell at the boy, but she didn't want to reproach him for telling the truth about the situation.

repudiate.example: Many in the public believed the rumors of a UFO crash outside town, so the chief of police did everything he could to repudiate the rumors.

rescind.example: The man's driver's license was rescinded after his tenth car accident, which meant he would never be allowed to legally drive again.

restive.example: The crowd grew restive as the comedian's opening jokes fell flat.

resurgent.example: The team sank to fourth place in June, but is now resurgent and about to win the division.
resurgent.meaning: rising again as to new life and vigor

reticent.example: When asked about her father, Helen lost her outward enthusiasm and became rather reticent.
reticent.meaning: reluctant to draw attention to yourself; temperamentally disinclined to talk

reverent.example: The professor could speak objectively about the other composers, but he always lectured about Brahms with a particularly reverent air, unable to offer a single criticism of his compositions.
reverent.meaning: feeling or showing profound respect or veneration

rudimentary.example: principles I would love to be able to present a fully polished proposal to the board, but right now, our plans for the product are still in the most rudimentary stages.
rudimentary.meaning: being in the earliest stages of development; being or involving basic facts or

rustic.example: The vacation cabin had no electricity and no indoor plumbing, but despite these inconveniences, Nigel adored its rustic charm.
rustic.meaning: characteristic of rural life; awkwardly simple and provincial

sanction.example: The authorities have sanctioned the use of the wilderness reserve for public use; many expect to see hikers an campers enjoying the park in the coming months.
International sanctions have been placed on certain shipping lanes that were thought to be involved in human trafficking.
sanction.meaning: a legal penalty for a forbidden action

scrupulous.example: Because of his scrupulous nature, Mary put him in charge of numbering and cataloging the entire collection of rare stamps.
scrupulous.meaning: characterized by extreme care and great effort

scrupulous.example: Everyone trusted what he said and followed his example because he was scrupulous and honest.
scrupulous.meaning: having a sense of right and wrong; principled

soporific.example: Although the professor is brilliant, his bland monotone gives his lectures a soporific effect.

specious.example: Almost every image on TV is specious and not to be trusted.
He made a career out of specious arguments and fictional lab results, but lost his job and reputation when his lies were exposed by an article in The New York Times.

sporadic.example: The signals were at first sporadic, but now we detect a clear, consistent pattern of electromagnetic radiation eminating from deep space.
sporadic.meaning: recurring in scattered and irregular or unpredictable instances

spurious.example: When listening to a politician speak, it is hard to distinguish the spurious claims from the authentic ones.

staunch.example: No longer a staunch supporter of the movement, Todd now will openly question whether its goals are worthwhile.
staunch.meaning: firm and dependable especially in loyalty

stringent.example: Most of the students disliked the teacher because of his stringent homework policy, but many students would later thank him for demanding so much from them.
stringent.meaning: demanding strict attention to rules and procedures

subsume.example: The rogue wave quickly subsumed the pier and boardwalk, destroying everything in its path.
Don Quixote of La Mancha subsumes all other modern novels, demonstrating modern literary devices and predating even the idea of a postmodern, metanarrative.
subsume.meaning: consider (an instance of something) as part of a general rule or principle

subversive.example: The ruling political party has begun a campaign to shut down subversive websites that it deems as a threat to "national safety."
subversive.meaning: in opposition to a civil authority or government

sullen.example: Herbert took board games too seriously, often appearing sullen after losing.

superfluous.example: How can we hope to stay open if we don't eliminate all superfluous spending, like catered meetings and free acupucture Tuesday?
Everything in this closet is superfluous and can be given to charity.
superfluous.meaning: more than is needed, desired, or required

supplant.example: For many, a cell phone has supplanted a traditional phone; in fact, most 20-somethings don't even have a traditional phone anymore.
supplant.meaning: take the place or move into the position of

sycophant.example: The CEO was unaware of the damaging consequences of his choices, largely because he surrounded himself with sycophants who would never dare criticize him.
sycophant.meaning: a person who tries to please someone in order to gain a personal advantage

taciturn.example: While the CEO enthusiastically shares his plans and agenda with all who will listen, the CFO is far more taciturn, rarely revealing his perspective.

tantamount.example: In many situations, remaining silent is tantamount to admitting guilt, so speak to prove your innocence.

temperance.example: Welles wasn't known for his temperance--he usually ate enough for two and drank enough for three.

tempered.example: The wide-eyed optimism of her youth was now tempered after she had worked many years in the criminal justice system.

tenacious.example: Even the most tenacious advocates for gun ownership must admit some of the dangers that firearms present.

timorous.example: Since this was her first time debating on stage and before an audience, Di's voice was timorous and quiet for the first 10 minutes.
timorous.meaning: timid by nature or revealing fear and nervousness

torpor.example: After work, I was expecting my colleagues to be enthusiastic about the outing, but I found them in a state of complete torpor.
torpor.meaning: inactivity resulting from lethargy and lack of vigor or energy

tortuous.example: Because the logic behind McMahon's side of the debate was so tortuous, his audience came out either completely confused or, worse, feeling they'd been tricked.
tortuous.meaning: marked by repeated turns and bends; not straightforward

tractable.example: taught or molded) Compared to middle school students, who have an untamed wildness about them, high school students are somewhat more tractable.
tractable.meaning: readily reacting to suggestions and influences; easily managed (controlled or

transient.example: The unpredictable and transient nature of deja vu makes it a very difficult phenomenon to study properly.

travesty.example: What I expected to be an intelligent, nuanced historical documentary turned out to be a poorly-produced travesty of the form.
travesty.meaning: an absurd presentation of something; a mockery

treacherous.example: Even though Jesse James was an outlaw, his killer, Robert Ford, is remembered more for his treacherous actions than for eliminating a criminal and murder.
The bridge built from twine and vine is treacherous to walk across, and so I think I will stay put right here.

trite.example: Many style guides recommend not using idioms in writing because these trite expressions are uninteresting and show a lack of imagination on the part of the writer.
trite.meaning: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse

truncate.example: The soccer game was truncated when the monsoon rain began to fall.

undermine.example: The student undermined the teacher's authority by questioning the teacher's judgment on numerous occasions.
undermine.meaning: to weaken (usually paired with an abstract term)

underscore.example: While the hiking instructor agreed that carrying a first aid kit could be a good idea under certain circumstances, he underscored the importance of carrying enough water.

unequivocal.example: interpretation and leading to only one conclusion The President's first statement on the subject was vague and open to competing interpretations, so when he spoke to Congress about the same subject later, he was cafeful to make his position completely unequivocal.
unequivocal.meaning: admitting of no doubt or misunderstanding; having only one meaning or

unscrupulous.example: In the courtroom, the lawyer was unscrupulous, using every manner of deceit and manipulation to secure a victory for himself.

upbraid.example: Bob took a risk walking into the "Students Barbershop"--in the end he had to upbraid the apparently drunk barber for giving him an uneven bowl cut.

vacillate.example: action Some students vacillate between schools when deciding which to attend, while others focus only on one school.
vacillate.meaning: be undecided about something; waver between conflicting positions or courses of
vacillate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

vehement.example: While the other employees responded to the bad news in a measured way, Andrew responded in a vehement manner, tipping over his desk and shouting at the top of his lungs.
vehement.meaning: marked by extreme intensity of emotions or convictions

venality.example: Even some of the most sacrosanct sporting events are not immune to venality, as many of the officials have received substantial bribes to make biased calls.
venality.meaning: the condition of being susceptible to bribes or corruption

venerate.example: The professor, despite his soporific lectures, was venerated amongst his colleagues, publishing more papers yearly than all of his peers combined.

veracious.example: While we elect our leaders in the hope that every word they speak will be veracious, history has shown that such a hope is naive.

vilify.example: Todd was noble after the divorce, choosing to say only complimentary things about Barbara, but Barbara did not hesitate to vilify Todd.

vindicate.example: Even seven Tour de France wins cannot vindicate Lance Armstrong in the eyes of the public--that the athlete used performance enhancing drugs invalidates all those wins.
vindicate.meaning: to clear of accusation, blame, suspicion, or doubt with supporting arguments or proof

vociferous.example: In giving Marcia a particular vociferous response, Paul caused people at every other table in the restaurant to turn around an look at them angrily.
vociferous.meaning: conspicuously and offensively loud; given to vehement outcry

volubility.example: The professor's volubility knows no bounds; he could talk through a hurricane and elaborate a point from one St. Patrick's Day to the next.
volubility.meaning: the quality of talking or writing easily and continuously

wanting.example: She did not think her vocabulary was wanting, yet there were so many words that inevitably she found a few she didn't know.
